newsitem.title: CANADA: Canada Board sets hearing on oil pipeline reversal.
newsitem.headline: Canada Board sets hearing on oil pipeline reversal.

text.p: Canada's National Energy Board said on Friday it would hold a two-phase public hearing on IPL Energy Inc's application to reverse the flow of its Sarnia-Montreal oil pipeline.

The move, which has the support of western Canadian oil producers, would allow imported crude oil to be shipped on the pipeline -- called Line 9 -- to Ontario and U.S. Midwest refineries by April 1, 1998.
IPL has said it estimated the cost of reversing the 832 km (517 mile) line's flow at C$89 million.
The offshore crude oil would be imported into Canada through the Portland-Montreal pipeline system.

The pipeline, which has had only trickles of western Canadian oil flow through it in the last few years, was a holdover from the energy crises of the 1970s, when the Canadian government wanted Quebec refiners to have a steady source of Canadian oil.
Line 9, which was completed in 1976 and operated under heavy government subsidy, shipped an average of 240,000 barrels per day until the mid-1980s.

After Canada's oil industry was deregulated in 1985, western Canadian crude oil deliveries to Montreal dropped as refiners opted for lower-cost imported supply. The closure of four Montreal-area refineries further cut demand.
The NEB said phase one of the hearing, expected to address tolling, tariff and economic issues, was slated to start in Calgary on August 5.
Phase two, expected to cover environmental and landowner issues, was set for August 11 in London, Ontario, the NEB said.
It said intervenors were to file with the board by June 19.
IPL said the initial capacity of the reversed line would be 160,000 barrels a day rising later to 240,000. ((Reuters Calgary Bureau (403) 531-1624))
